entry.title: SAP’s Commitment to Business Continuity that Protects what Matters
entry.content:
When people want to guard valuable items from their personal collections, they turn to protected places, such as banks, where they can rest safely, shielded from any unanticipated events. For centuries, individuals have entrusted institutions to safeguard what is most treasured by them, whether personal belongings or other assets. In the same fashion, SAP is dedicated to assisting customers protect their business value.

Disruptions can happen at any time. The difference stands in how well-prepared customers can be for these challenging periods. For example, Black Friday and Cyber Monday are the busiest shopping periods of the year for retailers. During these events, downtime or poor performance can cost millions in lost sales and customer trust, which could hamper core business operations.

Holiday Season Readiness Program

To support industries processes during these times, SAP enhanced the Holiday Season Readiness Program for Commerce Cloud customers. This joint initiative between Support, Engineering, and Cloud Operations ensured retailers were fully equipped with:

  • Introduction of a Preventative Care Model powered by AI and automation, using the Agentic AI framework to proactively detect and even resolve issues before they impacted customers.
  • Weekly health checks, 360° action plans, proactive cases, and a 24x7 global control room with real-time monitoring and on-site staffing.

SAP for Me

Aligned with our commitment to being a reliable partner, SAP for Me is evolving into a customer’s digital companion, in one of the most exciting innovations within SAP. It’s no longer just a portal; it’s becoming a central hub for transparency, guidance, and predictive insights. It holds:

  • AI-driven transparency - SAP for Me aggregates critical alerts, metrics, and insights across a customer’s entire SAP product portfolio. With the integration of Business AI, it now gives visibility into AI unit availability, consumption, and expirations, helping customers avoid surprises and plan proactively.
  • Proactive business assurance - Instead of waiting for a billing or system issue, SAP for Me provides real-time and predictive views into usage, health, and risks. For instance, customers can track consumption trends by product and feature, updated hourly, and receive early warnings when capacity is at risk.
  • Simplified control - All AI usage is linked to finance and legal statements, so customers get a single source of truth that connects technical consumption with business accountability. This prevents overspend, protects return on investment (ROI), and ensures contractual clarity.
  • Continuous innovation - SAP is expanding SAP for Me with embedded AI copilots and guided recommendations, so in the future, customers won’t just see metrics — they’ll get actionable guidance on how to optimize systems and safeguard value.

Ongoing support and maintenance are critical to sustaining business value with SAP systems. A successful go-live is just the starting point; systems need to remain secure, compliant, and optimized as business needs to evolve. With proactive monitoring, automation, and AI-driven insights, customers can prevent disruptions, reduce risk, and maintain high availability. In practice, this means lower operational costs, higher uptime, and continuous ROI over the entire lifecycle of their SAP investment.

Just as we expect care when trusting our valuables to others, SAP is committed to safeguarding business value, providing seamless experiences that protect decisive revenue and build sustained trust.

A special thanks to Keith Ho, Customer Engagement Lead, and Manoj Gupta, SAP experts who have contributed to this article.

entry.title: Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
entry.content:
Intro

Outbound interfaces are the lifeline between your new S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition system and the outside world. Customers, vendors, 3PL partners, they still expect the same EDI (or non-EDI) output messages, even if you’ve reshaped half your internal processes in the course of the SAP S/4HANA transformation.  

The real challenge? Functional consultants need to validate those outbound messages themselves, without waiting on an EDI provider, an integration colleague, or an EDI partner. That’s where Agentic AI validation with Int4 Suite comes in.

This playbook shows how functional consultants can independently test and validate outbound interfaces, step by step, without leaving the SAP S/4HANA + Int4 Suite environment.

Why functional consultants, not integration teams?

Most SAP projects (Greenfield, Selective Data Transition, or any other complex SAP S/4HANA upgrades) involve huge shifts inside SAP, but the outside world doesn’t care. Partner EDI flows must remain identical.

Traditionally, testing those flows meant:

  • Asking the EDI partner/provider for some sample messages
  • Trying to run the transaction in SAP S/4HANA
  • Asking the EDI provider to re-check/confirm outbound messages.
  • Pulling in a specialist from the integration team if something takes too long.
  • Repeating the same process multiple times with very little time to do it

Our approach flips this. It empowers the SAP functional consultant to:

  • Insert thousand of historical EDI messages from any productive system
  • Ask Int4 Suite to find the test data within those messages
  • Reproduce SAP transactions from historical payloads, like Sales Order Confirmation, Delivery (ASN) notification, Invoice Notification
  • Validate the EDI outbound messages directly in Int4 Suite by the functional consultant
  • The whole process takes minutes not hours and can be done hundreds of times per hour with no external dependencies (other partners)

No waiting on specialists, no bottlenecks, and much faster iterations.

Step 1: Reality-first message mining with Robotic Crawler

Use the Int4 Robotic Crawler to load hundreds or thousands of real historical messages (EDI or otherwise) into Int4 Suite. These are not toy examples — they’re your actual outbound payloads as they once moved through production.

Figure - Int4 Suite Robotic Crawler can fetch EDI messages from any supported archive or integration platform on mass scale 

Why it matters: Consultants can work with authentic data, not spec sheets or made-up test cases.

Step 2: Conversational selection of test cases

Functional consultants don’t need to master payload filtering. Instead, they can simply chat with the agent to select which messages they want to test.

Want to see all outbound orders from a specific customer? Or deliveries with a particular Incoterm? Just ask the agent.

Figure - select a historical EDI messages using different criteria (business document, partner, material, etc.) and use this data for testing 

Why it matters: Test-case discovery becomes intuitive, not a technical exercise.

Step 3: Reconstruct SAP business objects from payloads

Once a message is selected, the consultant can instantly recreate a business document (e.g., a Sales Order) inside S/4HANA using the data from that outbound message.

Figure - creating a sales order using the data from the historical EDI message as input 

Now you have a living document in S/4HANA, built directly from the same payload your partners receive.

Why it matters: Consultants can validate the end-to-end logic of their own functional processes, with no dependency on integration experts.

Step 4: Agentic comparison of original vs. new outbound message

After posting the new Sales Order (or Delivery, or Invoice), the consultant sends the newly generated outbound reference back to the AI agent. The agent compares this outbound message to the original one from Step 1.

Figure - use the historical EDI message to compare with the new one and fetch is by just supplying the new order reference number 

Are they still identical? Has anything in S/4HANA configuration changed the outbound structure? Did the partner-facing fields remain untouched?

Figure - display the comparison of the two EDI messages (original and the new one) to fix any SAP S/4HANA configuration issues (like line item category determination, substitutions, calculations, etc.) 

Why it matters: Consultants get a precise answer immediately, without needing to export messages into external systems or call for backup.

Who benefits from this approach?

  • Functional consultants in SAP S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition projects who must ensure message stability despite deep process changes.
  • Project teams that want faster, independent validation without pulling scarce EDI resources.
  • Business stakeholders who need assurance that partners will keep receiving the same documents as before, no surprises.

Who is this not for?

  • Integration consultants looking to stress-test iFlows or middleware mappings — this isn’t their playground. Int4 Suite has other features to facilite those requirements.
  • EDI providers who validate full partner connectivity, that’s still their domain.
  • Pure developers focused on code-level regression, this approach is tailored for business-facing validation.

Why it matters for S/4HANA programs where EDI messages remain the same but SAP S/4HANA can change? 

Outbound interfaces are always the fragile bridge in any migration. By equipping functional consultants with agentic AI validation, you:

  • Shorten test cycles.
  • Reduce reliance on external partners.
  • Increase confidence in project quality.

Outbound messages stay consistent, partners stay happy, and your SAP S/4HANA Greenfield program keeps its velocity.

This approach isn’t about replacing integration experts — it’s about freeing functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves the system is still what the outside world expects. It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction interface validation in SAP transformations.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here’s the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: “learn a test framework and run automated scripts,” we can say: “here are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.”

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a “Black Friday” scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure – run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure – fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn’t care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn’t about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It’s about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

entry.title: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly | Innovación segura, automatización inteligente y futuro sostenible
entry.content:
🛡️ 1️⃣ Seguridad mejorada en BTP: rotación automática de claves y CAPTCHA ampliado

🔹 SAP anunció en su Q3 2025 mejoras clave en Security & Identity Management. 🔹 Incluye rotación automática de claves de acceso, nuevos logs de aprovisionamiento en tiempo real y protección CAPTCHA incluso para verificación telefónica. 🔹 También llegan comandos de consola para certificados personalizados.

💬 Análisis: SAP sigue fortaleciendo la capa operativa de seguridad. La rotación automática reduce riesgos humanos, pero exige revisar integraciones para que las apps soporten las nuevas claves. Además, las APIs y logs abren la puerta a integraciones con SIEM corporativos.

📎 Q3 2025 Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security & IAM ❓ ¿Tus pipelines ya contemplan rotación automática de credenciales o siguen siendo manuales?

🧱 2️⃣ Riesgos en arquitecturas híbridas: seguridad entre BTP y el core

El crecimiento de BTP en entornos híbridos trajo nuevos retos: ⚙️ conexiones mal configuradas, 👤 cuentas técnicas con privilegios excesivos, 🚨 y falta de monitoreo entre sistemas on-premise y cloud.

Onapsis recomienda aplicar el principio de menor privilegio, segmentar destinos y usar alertas de comportamiento anómalo.

💬 Análisis: La promesa del híbrido es flexibilidad, pero también implica más puntos vulnerables. Cada destino en BTP es una posible puerta lateral si no se gestiona bien. La buena noticia: SAP ya integra alertas y trazabilidad más robustas; la mala, que muchas organizaciones aún no tienen visibilidad unificada de sus conexiones. Un gobierno efectivo requiere mapear todos los destinos, controlar privilegios y automatizar validaciones.Para el CIO, esto no es un problema técnico: es un riesgo reputacional si una brecha surge desde el entorno cloud.

📎 Securing the Bridge – Onapsis

🎓 3️⃣ SAP TechEd 2025: confianza, IA y estrategia BTP

📍 Berlín y online | 4–6 noviembre Este año, SAP TechEd pone el foco en IA responsable, seguridad y automatización empresarial. La pista “Building Trust on BTP” mostrará cómo aplicar IA generativa con cumplimiento normativo, y habrá nuevas certificaciones en SAP Build y AI Developer.

💬 Análisis: TechEd siempre marca tendencias. Este año, SAP busca demostrar que IA y seguridad no son opuestos, sino complementarios. La idea de “trust by design” será central: usar IA generativa bajo marcos de control auditables. Para los arquitectos, esto significa que el BTP no solo será más inteligente, sino también más predecible. Y para los líderes de negocio, TechEd será el momento de evaluar cómo conectar Joule y Build con la realidad operativa.

📎 Agenda oficial SAP TechEd 2025

🤖 4️⃣ Joule Studio y automatización inteligente

SAP Joule Studio permite crear agentes de IA sin código directamente sobre Build Process Automation. Un CFO o analista puede describir en lenguaje natural un proceso, y Joule lo convierte en flujo automatizado. El reto: asegurar trazabilidad y control en automatizaciones generadas por usuarios.

💬 Análisis: Este paso cambia el juego: los procesos dejan de ser diseñados solo por TI. Con Joule Studio, áreas como Finanzas o RRHH pueden construir automatizaciones útiles en minutos. Sin embargo, el reto está en la gobernanza: definir quién puede crear, auditar y modificar esos flujos. El CIO gana velocidad, pero debe mantener control. El equilibrio entre autonomía y seguridad definirá el éxito.

📎 SAP Joule Studio

♻️ 5️⃣ FinOps y sostenibilidad: control financiero y ambiental en una sola vista

SAP refuerza su visión ESG con Sustainability Control Tower y Green Ledger, integradas con BTP y S/4HANA Cloud. CFOs y COOs pueden medir impacto ambiental junto al financiero, automatizando reportes ESG. Combinado con FinOps, permite reducir gastos cloud y alinear sostenibilidad y rentabilidad.

💬 Análisis: El control financiero y la sostenibilidad se vuelven inseparables. BTP permite que el impacto ambiental se mida con el mismo rigor que el financiero. Para el CFO, significa tener visibilidad completa de costos y emisiones. Para TI, implica integrar métricas ESG dentro de los procesos operativos. Este enfoque convierte la sostenibilidad en una ventaja competitiva, no en un “compliance más”.

📎 SAP Sustainability Control Tower

🧩 6️⃣ Extensibilidad guiada: el “wizard” que simplifica SAP Build y CAP

El nuevo Extensibility Wizard ayuda a construir extensiones seguras para S/4HANA desde BTP, asegurando compatibilidad con upgrades y manteniendo el clean core. Menos “custom code spaghetti”, más agilidad y trazabilidad.

💬 Análisis: SAP da un paso firme hacia la estandarización de extensiones. El wizard facilita que incluso equipos sin experiencia profunda en ABAP construyan ampliaciones seguras y mantenibles. Esto acelera proyectos sin comprometer el core. El desafío: convencer a los equipos de desarrollo tradicionales de abandonar el “custom code” artesanal y adoptar un enfoque guiado, pero más sostenible.

📎 Extensibility Wizard – Blog SAP

🔗 7️⃣ Joule + Microsoft Copilot: colaboración aumentada entre ecosistemas

La alianza SAP–Microsoft da un paso más: Joule se integra con Microsoft 365 Copilot, permitiendo consultar y accionar datos SAP directamente desde Teams, Outlook o Excel. Ejemplo: “¿Cuál fue el gasto real del Q3?” — y Joule responde en segundos con datos de SAP Analytics Cloud. Una nueva forma de productividad aumentada, donde BTP se convierte en el puente entre AI empresarial y colaboración diaria.

💬 Análisis: La frontera entre ERP y oficina se difumina. Con Joule + Copilot, un usuario puede consultar información crítica de SAP sin salir de Teams. Esto convierte la colaboración diaria en un entorno de decisión asistida por IA. Para los CIOs, implica una nueva prioridad: gobernar el acceso a datos sensibles que ahora fluyen por herramientas colaborativas. Una integración poderosa, pero que exige políticas sólidas de seguridad y contexto de uso.

📎 SAP + Microsoft AI Partnership

¿Qué equilibrio te resulta más desafiante hoy? 👉 Seguridad 👉 Velocidad 👉 Gobernanza

Déjamelo en los comentarios — la transformación BTP la construimos entre todos 💬

entry.title: Intelligent Natural-Language Interaction in ABAP UIs — Introducing the FPM GenAI Service
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

With the upcoming ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 Private Cloud Edition, the new FPM GenAI Service offers a new way to bring AI-powered interaction into classical FPM-based applications.
This service can be consumed via SAP BTP credits and is designed to seamlessly integrate large language models (LLMs) into ABAP-based UIs.

The Floorplan Manager (FPM) UI Framework provides an especially suitable foundation for this, thanks to its event-based control flow and stateful backend integration — both essential for combining generative AI logic with transactional business processes.

What is the FPM GenAI Service?

The FPM GenAI Service enables developers to connect their FPM applications with LLMs in order to interpret natural-language user input and transform it into application-specific operations at runtime.

Instead of navigating through the user interface in a traditional way, users can simply express their intent in natural language — for example:

“Please create a new business partner for SAP Deutschland SE & Co. KG”
“Show all open invoices from last month”

The service interprets the user’s request and executes the corresponding FPM events in the backend.

Key benefits:

  • Users no longer need expert-level knowledge about the UI or data model.

  • Reduced number of manual UI steps — one prompt replaces multiple operations.

  • Improved accessibility for occasional or business users.

Architecture Overview:

Architecture Overview of FPM GenAI Service

Step-by-Step Integration Guide for Application Developers

The following steps outline how to enable AI-driven interaction in an existing FPM application.

1. Define AI Use Cases

Collect all possible actions your application can perform that make sense for AI interaction.
Examples:

  • “Create a new business partner”

  • “Display all open sales orders for customer XYZ”

2. Define Parameters

Each operation may require parameters such as NAME, ADDRESS or SALES_ORDER_ID.
Collect them and describe how they relate to the operation.

3. Add Natural Language Descriptions

Provide concise, meaningful text descriptions for both operations and parameters.
Keep them short and precise — the LLM will use these to interpret prompts accurately.
(English is recommended for maintainability.)

4. Integrate AI into the UI

At the current stage, you can integrate the AI trigger via a button in your FPM toolbar.
In the demo applications, this is done using a button with an AI icon (sap-icon://ai), which opens the FPM Prompt RUIBB (component FPM_AI_QUICK_PROMPT).
A deeper integration with SAP Joule in the Fiori Launchpad is planned for the future.

5. Register Your Operations

Once your operations, parameters, and descriptions are ready, register them in the FPM GenAI Manager.

DATA: ls_operations TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_s_operation,
      lt_operations TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_t_operation,
      ls_parameter  TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_s_parameter.

ls_operations-event_id    = 'AI_CREATE_BP'.
ls_operations-description = 'create a new business partner (BP)'.
ls_parameter-name         = 'COMPANY_NAME'.
ls_parameter-description  = 'only the company name (without legal form)'.
APPEND ls_parameter TO ls_operations-parameters.
APPEND ls_operations TO lt_operations.

DATA(lo_fpm_genai_manager) = cl_fpm_factory=>get_instance( )->get_genai_manager( ).
lo_fpm_genai_manager->set_operations( lt_operations ).

It’s recommended to register only those operations that are relevant to the current screen — this keeps prompts short and improves accuracy.

6. Execute the User Request

When the user submits a prompt, obtain the GenAI Manager API and call:

lo_fpm_genai_manager->execute_user_request( ).

7. Process the FPM Event

After receiving the LLM response, the FPM GenAI Manager creates and raises FPM events.
Handle these events in your implementation of IF_FPM_UI_BUILDING_BLOCK, typically in the method PROCESS_EVENT( ).

8. Handle Errors Gracefully

Use exception class CX_FPM_GENAI for error handling.
Possible cases include:

  • NO_USER_INPUT

  • USER_INPUT_ERROR

  • NO_OPERATIONS

  • GENAI_SDK_ERROR

Use the FPM Message Manager to communicate errors back to the user:

DATA(lo_msg_manager) = cl_fpm_factory=>get_instance( )->get_message_manager( ).
lo_msg_manager->report_error( cx_fpm_genai=>get_text( ) ).

That's everything for now 🙂 Now, let's check out the first

Example: EPM Demo Application (S_EPM_UX_BP)

The EPM demo application (S_EPM_UX_BP) has been enhanced to showcase the new GenAI capabilities.
The scenario demonstrates how the AI assistant can help with tasks such as creating business partners, listing products, and generating sales orders.

Step 1 – Create a New Business Partner

From the result list toolbar, select the AI button (“New”) and enter one of the following prompts:

“Please add a new business partner in the role customer, name = SAP Deutschland SE & Co. KG, street = Hasso-Plattner-Ring 7, city = 69190 Walldorf.”
“Hi, we have a new customer: SAP SE Deutschland. Copy the details from their imprint page.”

Each of these prompts triggers the creation of a new business partner in the “Customer” role.

Next, the user can ask for product recommendations:

entry.title: What's new in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model – September 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I’m happy to announce that the September release of SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) is available. It’s packed with many great new features! This blog post highlights some of the new features. It presents a range of exciting new capabilities, such as the new MCP servers or the integration with Application Frontend service. In addition, we collected some informative blog posts delving into various aspects of CAP and give you an overview on upcoming events.

Check out the details of what's new!

 

Enabling Agentic Development with MCP Servers

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that bridges the gap between large language models (LLMs) and external resources such as services, tools, data, and workflows, so models can fetch context, take actions, and deliver more accurate results. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code.

Beginning of September, SAP introduced MCP servers for CAP, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5. These MCP servers are designed specifically for building enterprise-grade SAP business applications taking into account proven best practices and providing recommendations tailored to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Welcome to cap-js/mcp-server

For further information, I highly recommend you to read this blog post: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable agentic development for Enterprise Applications.

 

Easily Integrate with Application Frontend Service

The Application Frontend service is a SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), which serves as a single entry point for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications. It is part of SAP Build, SAP’s unified solution for application development and process automation. By consolidating all aspects of UI application management under one managed service, Application Frontend service simplifies the development experience and enhances custom application operations. For an introduction to Application Frontend service, please read this blog post.

With our latest CAP release it is now possible to easily integrate the Application Frontend service. All you have to do is use the command cds add app-frontend. This adds all the needed configuration to your project providing you access to Application Frontend’s cool features. No additional work for you to do!

Please note: The support for this service is currently limited to single-tenant applications.

 

Integration with SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh now Generally Available

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh enables real-time, asynchronous communication. It works across hybrid, multi-cloud, and edge environments. The advanced event mesh integrates SAP and non-SAP systems into your event-driven architecture and allows you to form meshes of event brokers. You can publish and subscribe to business events from all kinds of SAP and non-SAP event sources. As a result, event-driven architecture and advanced event mesh keep systems and users up to date when critical changes occur. Advanced event mesh allows to manage, monitor, and visualize decentralized event streaming across your landscape.

In May, we released the beta version of our integration with advanced event mesh. After a successful test and evaluation phase, we are now happy to tell you that both open-source plugins (for Node.js and for Java) are now generally available (GA). The GA release comes with a notable addition: the support for cross-subaccount broker validation, allowing you to share advanced event mesh instances between multiple subaccounts.

Additional details can be found here.

 

Translated Error Messages in CAP Node.js

For a better user experience, error messages that appear on the UI should be translated into the same language as the rest of their application. Therefore, CAP Node.js delivers translations for annotation-based input validations out of the box in all CAP-supported languages. For a list of the messages that are currently translated, see the documentation.

Screenshot: Translation of error codes to German language

To learn more about error handling in Node.js, please read the following section in the documentation. For additional information about internationalization in Node.js, check out this section.

For those of you, who use CAP Java: translated error messages are also supported there. Please look at the documentation, to gain further insights.

 

Further Readings & Events

Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP

Using CSV files to load initial data or sample data is convenient but you must be careful when deploying data to SAP S/4HANA Cloud as you might risk losing data. In his blog post Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP, SAP Champion Mio Yasutake explains alternative approaches how to avoid data loss.

 

Providing Feedback on CAP Documentation

Your feedback is crucial for us to improve. Thus, we would like to ask you to share your feedback on our CAP documentation. There are many ways to provide us your feedback. In his blog post Multiple Ways to Give Feedback on CAP Documentation, my colleague Rene guides you through the different options.

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Customer Roundtable

The next CAP Customer Roundtable is just around the corner. If you are interested in an overview of the recent features, demos, presentations and questions raised by the CAP community, mark your calendar for October 15th, 2025, 11 AM EST | 5 PM CE(S)T. Find further details (including the agenda and dial in data) in this blog post.

 

Devtoberfest 2025

Devtoberfest 2025 already started. In 2025, the event is taking place from September 29th until October 24th. But you can still consume the content. Devtoberfest is a virtual event giving SAP developers a great opportunity to get ready for SAP TechEd. It is packed with enablement sessions around topics in the area of CAP, ABAP, Tooling and Frontend, Integration, Data and AI, combined with a lot of fun. For further information, read the Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome! blog post and join the Devtoberfest group in SAP Community to take part in this great event!

 

SAP TechEd 2025

From November 4–6, 2025 SAP TechEd takes place providing you the opportunity to learn about the latest innovations and advancements in SAP technologies and to connect with the community. In 2025, SAP TechEd will be a hybrid event combining the best of both worlds: the in-person event in Berlin and the virtual event. Both events are taking place in parallel. Make sure to save the date and register now for Berlin or virtual!

The session catalogs for the in-person and the virtual event are now live, featuring a wide range of topics across various tracks, where you'll find many sessions on the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model.

 

For further information on new features, please have a look at the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Release Notes. If you want to stay up-to-date with news, learning resources, and product and strategy updates for CAP: follow our tag in the SAP Community.

We look forward to seeing how you use these new capabilities to create innovative solutions and drive your projects forward. Stay tuned for more updates and happy coding! 😊

entry.title: Self Refining Prompts for a better Customer Experience
entry.content:
Teaching AI applications to Self-Critique

My Experiments with Self-Refining prompts

Most of us treat a prompt like a one-shot instruction. You ask, the model answers, and… that’s it. But in practice, good work is iterative: we write a draft, critique it, and then refine. Self-Refine applies that same loop to AI — the model acts as writer, critic, and editor in quick succession until the result feels right.

In this post, I’ll share what clicked for me, a simple three-step pattern, and a few mini-experiments you can try (and screenshot) to see the lift for yourself.

The 3-Step Loop (that changed how I prompt)

1) Generate – Ask for the initial output.
2) Feedback – Ask the model to critique its own output with specific, actionable notes.
3) Refine – Tell it to rewrite using only that feedback.
Repeat until it says, “no further refinement.”

This is simple. The magic is in good feedback prompts (“point out tone, missing details, structure” vs. vague “improve it”).

How it works (in 10 seconds)

  • Generate: Draft the answer
  • Critique: The model reviews itself (JSON feedback + score)
  • Refine: It rewrites using that feedback
  • Stop: when the score plateaus or hits your bar

Task-specific effectiveness: Self-refinement works better for some task types (code generation, technical documentation) than others (creative writing). Measures vary for each task category.​

Mini-Experiments

Building a self-improving web search Agent 

Building a Web Search Agent with Self-Improving Prompts
The foundation combines SAP AI Core's Generative AI Hub with LangChain's Google Search wrapper:
```python
# SAP AI Core client setup
ai_core_client = AICoreV2Client(
    base_url=BASE_URL, auth_url=AUTH_URL,
    client_id=CLIENT_ID, client_secret=CLIENT_SECRET,
)
llm = init_llm(MODEL_NAME, temperature=0.0, max_tokens=512)

# Google Search integration
search = GoogleSearchAPIWrapper(k=5)
google_tool = Tool.from_function(
    name="google_search",
    description="Search Google and return the first results",
    func=search.run
)
agent = initialize_agent(tools=[google_tool], llm=llm, agent=AgentType.OPENAI_FUNCTIONS)

#This gives us both a base LLM and an agent that can search the web when needed.
The Three-Prompt Pattern
The self-refinement uses three distinct prompts with clear roles:
Generator Prompt: Creates initial draft without second-guessing
GEN_PROMPT = """You are a careful, precise assistant.
TASK: {task}
Produce the best possible answer. Do not include any self-critique here."""
```
Critic Prompt: Evaluates with structured feedback
CRITIC_PROMPT = """You are a meticulous reviewer. Given the TASK and the DRAFT answer,
1) list EXACTLY 3 concrete issues or improvement opportunities,
2) give a numbered improvement plan,
3) rate current quality from 0–100,
4) decide if refinement is still needed.

Respond with a SINGLE JSON object and NOTHING ELSE:
{{"issues": ["...", "...", "..."], "plan": ["step 1", "step 2", "step 3"], "score": 0, "stop": false}}"""
```
Refiner Prompt: Applies improvements systematically
REFINE_PROMPT = """You are a senior editor. Apply the plan below to improve the DRAFT.
Keep all correct content; fix issues; increase clarity, correctness, and usefulness.
Return ONLY the improved answer (no commentary)."""```
The key is separating generation from critique to avoid the model sabotaging its own initial work.
The Self-Refine Loop
def self_refine(
    task: str,
    max_iters: int = 3,
    min_delta: int = 2,
    use_agent_for_initial: bool = False
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """
    Self-refine loop: GENERATE -> CRITIQUE -> REFINE until stop or plateau.
    Returns final answer and iteration history.
    """
    history: List[Dict[str, Any]] = []

    # 1) Initial draft
    draft = call_llm_text(GEN_PROMPT.format(task=task), use_agent=use_agent_for_initial)
    history.append({"iteration": 0, "draft": draft, "score": None, "feedback": None})

    best = draft
    best_score = -math.inf

    for i in range(1, max_iters + 1):
        # 2) Critique
        critic_raw = call_llm_text(CRITIC_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft))
        critic = extract_json_block(critic_raw)

        # Safety coerce
        issues = critic.get("issues", [])[:3]
        plan = critic.get("plan", [])
        score = int(critic.get("score", 50))
        stop_flag = bool(critic.get("stop", False))

        history.append({
            "iteration": i,
            "draft": draft,
            "score": score,
            "feedback": {"issues": issues, "plan": plan, "raw": critic_raw}
        })

        # Plateau / stop condition
        if stop_flag and i > 1:
            break
        if best_score != -math.inf and (score - best_score) < min_delta and i > 1:
            # No meaningful improvement
            break

        # Track best
        if score > best_score:
            best = draft
            best_score = score

        # 3) Refine
        plan_str = "\n".join(f"- {p}" for p in plan) if plan else "- Improve clarity and correctness."
        refined = call_llm_text(REFINE_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft, plan=plan_str))
        draft = refined

    # Final scoring pass to attach a last score
    final_critic_raw = call_llm_text(CRITIC_PROMPT.format(task=task, draft=draft))
    final_critic = extract_json_block(final_critic_raw) or {"score": best_score if best_score != -math.inf else None}
    final_score = int(final_critic.get("score", best_score if best_score != -math.inf else 0))

    return {
        "task": task,
        "final": draft,
        "final_score": final_score,
        "history": history,
        "final_critic_raw": final_critic_raw
    }
Usage Example
# runner + example usage
def run_task_self_refine(
    task: str,
    max_iters: int = 3,
    min_delta: int = 2,
    use_agent_for_initial: bool = False,
    verbose: bool = True
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    result = self_refine(
        task=task,
        max_iters=max_iters,
        min_delta=min_delta,
        use_agent_for_initial=use_agent_for_initial
    )
    if verbose:
        for rec in result["history"]:
            it = rec["iteration"]
            pretty_print_blocks(f"Iteration {it} — Draft", rec["draft"])
            if rec["feedback"]:
                fb = rec["feedback"]
                pretty_print_blocks(f"Iteration {it} — Feedback (score={rec['score']})", json.dumps({
                    "issues": fb["issues"],
                    "plan": fb["plan"]
                }, indent=2))
        pretty_print_blocks(f"FINAL (score={result['final_score']})", result["final"])
    return result

# Example task (swap in anything you like)
Search_Query = "How to integrate SAP Shopping Assistant with SAP Commerce Cloud?"

result = run_task_self_refine(
    Search_Query, 
    max_iters=3, 
    min_delta=2, 
    use_agent_for_initial=True  # Use web search for initial draft
)
Setting `use_agent_for_initial=True` leverages the Google Search agent for the first draft when current information might be needed.
Using LLM, I compared all three outputs I got. Here is the result
ItemIteration 0Iteration 1 (Feedback)Iteration 2Iteration 2 (Feedback)FINAL
UI NavigationGenericAsk for detailed pathsAdds named tabs/panelsRequest more explicit stepsClear, step-by-step paths
PerformanceSeparate checklistAsk to integrate in stepsStill separateAsk for actionable guidanceEmbedded, actionable tips
ValidationBrief & vagueAsk to expand per componentIncompleteAsk for full, concrete checks10 concrete, testable checks
PitfallsShort list—SameAsk for fixesPitfalls paired with fixes
CompletenessOK—Cuts offAsk to finishComplete & ready to run
Key Benefits
-Quality Improvement: Typical 15-25 point score increases over 2-3 iterations
-Cost Control: Plateau detection prevents wasteful refinement cycles
-Flexibility: Can use plain LLM or web-search agent based on task needs
-Transparency: Full iteration history shows the improvement process
Quality Improvement Analysis ( So far, the best score that I achieved)
Score Progress  
Iteration 0:45/100Basic initial draft
Iteration 1:68/100+23 Points improvement
Iteration 2:87/100+19 Points improvement
 
Total Improvement: +42 points (93.3% increase)
 The Answers transformed from vague steps to specific, executable instructions

The simulation shows the typical self-refinement pattern where the biggest jump occurs in iteration 1 (+23 points), with diminishing but still valuable returns in iteration 2 (+19 points).

But here's the reality check: This represents a best-case scenario. During my experiments, I also encountered:

Complete refinement failures where systems produced identical content across iterations despite clear feedback, Content truncation issues where later iterations became incomplete, cutting off mid-sentence, Score plateaus where quality metrics stayed flat (75/100) even after visible improvements


The approach works especially well for tasks requiring accuracy and completeness, like coding, technical procedures, troubleshooting guides, and detailed explanations, where initial drafts often miss important details.
 
Self Improving Prompts - Example  -- This was the most common behavior 

What surprised me

  • The biggest gains come in the first 1–2 rounds. After that, returns fade.
  • Weak models can struggle to give good feedback. Strong instruction-following models do best. [ I call them the most obedient models:-)]
  • If feedback is vague, the rewrite is useless. If feedback is dimensioned and specific, the quality of the output excels.

How to use Self-Refine in a Customer Support Chatbot

Self-Refine is perfect for support bots because real customers are often vague (“my order didn’t arrive,” “can’t login”).

Goals

  • Clarify fast when the query is vague and has very less details.
  • Ground answers in your KB/CRM (no hallucinations).
  • Converge in 1–2 refinement rounds to keep latency low.
  • Escalate cleanly when confidence stays low.

 How can we model this?

TLDR for practitioners

Treat prompts like drafts. Ask the model to critique with structure, then refine under constraints. Screenshot the three steps (Generate → Feedback → Refine) to make the improvement visible. Once you see it, it’s hard to go back to one-shot prompting.

Self-refinement works better for some task types (code generation, technical documentation) than others (creative writing). 

Cost vs. quality tradeoff: Calculate the token cost per quality point gained. For some applications, a single well-crafted prompt may be more cost-effective than multiple iteration refinements.
Bottom line: self-refining prompts make your bot think twice—so customers don’t have to ask twice.

entry.title: Brazil as One of the Leading Hubs for Artificial Intelligence (2024–2025)
entry.content:
Over the past two years, Brazil has established itself as one of the main Artificial Intelligence (AI) hubs globally, standing out for its combination of public investments, expanding business ecosystem, and regulatory progress. Traditionally a leader in innovation and technology in Latin America, Brazil is now attracting international attention by accelerating the adoption of AI across strategic sectors such as finance, energy, agribusiness, and public services.

In 2024, the Brazilian government launched the Brazilian Artificial Intelligence Plan (PBIA) 2024–2028, a program with an estimated investment of R$ 23 billion dedicated to AI research, development, and infrastructure. The plan aims to strengthen technological sovereignty, foster innovation through universities, and support companies in applying AI to practical use cases, particularly in areas of public interest.

The Main pillars of the PBIA 2024–2028 are:

  • Expansion of AI research and innovation centers;
  • Tax incentives for startups and public–private partnerships;
  • Training and qualification of AI professionals;
  • Implementation of AI in public services (health, security, education).

This initiative positions Brazil as a regional leader in AI policy, ahead of countries like Mexico, Chile, and Argentina.

Brazil’s private sector is undergoing a phase of rapid AI adoption. By 2025, a national survey identified 396 Brazilian AI companies focused on marketing applications, reflecting diversification across generative AI, automation, analytics, and digital services.

According to a Bain & Company (2025) study, 67% of Brazilian companies now consider AI a strategic priority, a major leap from 2024, when only about 12% had active projects. This demonstrates the transition from experimental use to mature, production-level adoption.

Brazil received international investments and technological infrastructure. That's why Brazil’s consolidation as an AI hub also stems from the confidence of major global players. In September 2024, Microsoft announced a US$ 2.7 billion investment in cloud and AI infrastructure in Brazil, one of the largest technology investments in Latin American history. In 2025, Eletrobras partnered with C3 AI to modernize Brazil’s power grid using AI and machine learning, highlighting the industrial applications of advanced technologies.

These moves strengthen Brazil’s position as a regional hub for data and high-performance computing, essential for scaling generative AI and automation initiatives.

Despite major progress, Brazil still faces structural challenges. A SAP Brazil (March 2025) survey revealed that:

  • 29% of companies lack clarity on how to integrate AI into their business systems;
  • 28% cite a shortage of skilled professionals as the main obstacle.

On the regulatory front, Brazil has emerged as a key player. In 2024, the National Data Protection Authority (ANPD) suspended Meta Platforms’ privacy policy, which used Brazilians’ personal data to train generative AI models. This decision marked an important milestone in ethical governance and digital sovereignty, aligning Brazil with European-style data protection principles.

The main sectors driving AI growth in Brazil include:

  • Finance and digital payments: automation and predictive analytics;
  • Energy: smart grids and real-time system optimization;
  • Agribusiness: crop forecasting and climate analytics;
  • Healthcare: assisted diagnostics and telemedicine;
  • Public administration: chatbots and natural language processing for citizen services.

These industries attract investments from both large corporations and local startups, making Brazil a fertile ground for experimentation and innovation.

About the Outlook for 2025 and Beyond the trends indicate continued expansion of generative AI and process automation in Brazilian companies. By the end of 2025, it is expected that:

  • Over 60% of corporate AI solutions in Brazil will involve generative models;
  • The country will consolidate international research and training partnerships;
  • The General Artificial Intelligence Law (under discussion in Congress) will advance the national governance framework.

With growing public and private investments, Brazil is on track to become a Latin American reference in AI innovation and ethics, combining economic growth with responsible technological governance.

The 2024–2025 period marks a strategic turning point for AI in Brazil, shifting from an emerging topic to a core pillar of industrial and business competitiveness. The alignment between government vision, international investments, and technological maturity positions Brazil as one of the leading AI hubs in the Southern Hemisphere, with the potential to export technology, talent, and regulatory best practices.

At MakeValue, we develop AI-powered applications for SAP Finance, focused on enhancing financial visibility and decision-making. Our Cash Flow Intelligence App leverages data from Supply Chain, Sales, Treasury, Accounts Receivable, Accounts Payable, and real-time Bank Balances to deliver accurate forecasting and scenario simulation, ensuring that financial teams have a clear, data-driven view of their company’s liquidity at any time.

Is your company already exploring AI implementation projects? In which sectors or business processes are you seeing the greatest potential for transformation?

  • Reuters: Brazil proposes $4 billion AI investment plan

  • Bain & Company (2025): Artificial Intelligence Adoption Survey

In his interactive session, he polled the audience to give people a sense of how they compare to their peers in terms of innovation and adoption of various technologies. In the UX Strategy and What’s New section, Ioannis and Ute talked about the continuing evolution of SAP Fiori, how SAP Fiori elements brings the Fiori design system to apps in SAP S/4HANA, and demoed the Fiori experience in SAP Cloud ERP. They showed new AI-powered capabilities in My Home, such as Recap and recommendations, and explained how AI built into the SAP Fiori elements framework powers easy filter, smart summarization, and error explanation. All of this functionality combines to make business users more productive by making it faster and easier to find the apps and data they need in their S/4HANA system.

We had a day full of learning and fun.

In the partner panel, experts from Mygo Consulting, Qubittron, Mindset Consulting, and cbs Corporate Business Solutions shared their expertise on:

  • How organizations measure the return on investment for UX and AI projects.
  • Where AI playing a role in UX and how agents fit into the picture.
  • The relative value of AI for business users and developers.
  • The top AI use cases that make sense for companies
  • Where to focus your efforts in the near term to gain benefits from AI

Thanks to Sujeeth, Sidhartha, Andy, and Bastian for your unique insights and actionable advice. I found it interesting that many of the topics that people mentioned would be useful in the future were already part of our “one more thing” session at the end of the day.

The hands-on workshop focused on using AI to accelerate the process of building SAP Fiori apps. Participants used AI in three main ways:

  1. Gathering user requirements in a business requirement documents or via sketching
  2. Uploading the resulting document into SAP Fiori tools AI to generate an SAP Fiori elements app
  3. Making further updates and refinements to the application

We used SAP Fiori tools extensively. This is a logical choice since they are built into SAP Business Application Studio.

The final session of the day (and highest rated) was our lab preview / sneak peak at a few projects are currently in development. As with any discussion of future functionality, we made it clear that these demos might or might not turn into actual products. With this in mind, Sebastian and Katja showed:

  • Vibe coding using MCP servers. (Vibe coding was also part of the ASUG keynote, so this is clearly becoming a mainstream topic, at least among software developers.)
  • App Finder to make it easier to find information in your S/4HANA system.
  • Easy Fill, which speeds up data entry by extracting content from an email or other text and using it to update the relevant fields in an app built using an SAP Fiori elements object page.
  • Smart Helpers to make it easier to get your work done in SAP. I’m being deliberately vague here as we’ll share more at SAP TechEd and its companion roadshows in early November 2025.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

SAP Fiori Innovation Day sponsors: cbs Corporate Business Solutions, Mindset Consulting, Qubittron, and Mygo Consulting

All the customers: we appreciate your questions, which help us understand your priorities and focus our development resources.

entry.title: Generative AI, MCP and SAP; What are these and how to make the most of it?
entry.content:
Hi All,

Generative AI is the current buzzword in the market. Potentially, every clients, companies and adapting to it on fast pace. Recently SAP had introduced support for Model Context Protocol. With this particular blog, I'll be trying to make you all understand what MCP is, how we can make the best use of it for your SAP systems.

What is Model context protocol? (MCP)?
 It is basically an open, standardized approach that enables Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents to access up to date,  enterprise data - In our case, across SAP and other business systems on demand.

As Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT-4, Claude, Gemini, Llama3 etc evolve, we need standardized ways to connect them to tools, APIs, and systems. Imagine trying to follow different connectors/API for each LLM!
However, these models operate in isolation based on pre-trained data and don’t have built-in access to real-time data, databases , external APIs, or local files. Which is where MCP kicks in.

Below figure shows how MCP Client( Potentially LLMs or AI Agents) could connect to SAP systems.

MCP follows a client-server architecture, where:

  • Clients (like AI applications or LLMs) connect to
  • Servers (MCP tool providers) expose tools, APIs, or data sources to clients.

In our case, As an example- We can connect any AI agent to automate the workflows, or any AI models, using MCP to SAP systems, which would have access to the system and train from enterprise data.

Potential Use-cases:

  1. SAP GUI automation- Autonomous GUI Agent:

    Agent to automate interactions with SAP GUI, enabling programmatic control of SAP transactions. This can automate manual processes, activities which users perform on day to day basis.

    Automation scope:

    • Automation and workflows
    • Automating repetitive SAP business processes and transactions
    • Extracting specific data from SAP screens and tables for reporting or analysis
    • Integrating SAP GUI automation into AI-powered desktop assistants or custom applications

    How does it work?

    AI Agent can be fed with recorded steps, It can read and understand the fields, adapt with time; Unlike using RPA which is trained to exactly copy and execute the system actions.


    Advantage:
    Automate repetitive, heinous tasks.

  2. Enhanced Analytics and Reporting- Create dashboard and statistics.
    Scope:
    System reads, understands data and patterns and potentially (examples) answer below queries:

    “Whats the usage of product XXX?”
    “Tell me the product which is most used during XXX months/quarter?”

    Advantage:
    Build dashboards, reports instantly based on the data required

  3. Understand what custom functionality does, AI can read the code, Create of functional, technical documentations:

    Let’s consider a case where a vendor has done custom development and It is a blackbox to us, AI helps us to read, analyze and provide a basic understanding of the custom enhancement, saving time and efforts. The same can be extracted as documentation for future references.

    Examples:
    “Explain this legacy ABAP report in plain english and add detailed in-line comments”

    Result- Understand complex, undocumented Z-programs, making analysis and decisions faster.

  4.  Fiori MCP Server/Write UI5 code using agents:

    -Developers can build apps faster using MCP servers.
    -Write UI5 code using agents.

    Examples:
    “Add flexible row layout for the app”
    “Generate a new project and SAP Fiori app based on “my sketch.jpg”

    “How can I style an sap.m.Button to appear as a "reject" action?"
    "Help me migrate any deprecated UI5 API usage in this UI5 controller"

     

     

  5.  AI Assisted coding:

    MCP Clients to assist Consultants with coding, code reviews etc

  6. Smart IoT, Yard integrations, Smart Dock scheduling, Automated calls etc

    -Attain End to End track and trace information for Boxes with prompting

    -Dock Appointment scheduling using phone calls with AI voice assistant.

     

  7. Custom Chatbot- Only integrated for client data:

    End users can enquire, ask things to the chatbox which is integrated with SAP. (Can be Enabled for consultants as well).

    • Gain Information on business processes; In most organizations, Information relevant to any business process is often scattered across multiple business applications, databases, cloud systems, and files, both inside and outside of SAP. 
    • For AI agents to deliver meaningful answers and actions, they need access to all relevant data, not just data isolated SAP tables. 
    • With MCP, the connection between entire enterprise system and AI agents can be built easily.

     

  8.  How could this fit in EWM?

    Since I come from EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) background, These are few use-cases which I had in mind:
    • Custom Chatbot- only integrated for client data
    • Demand Forecasting- Enable models to predict future demand of products
    • Slotting & rearrangement- Suggest optimal bin placement for products- Helping drastically in production, Kanban processes, Urgent flows etc
    • Labour Management-Estimate, optimize workforce allocation.
    • Picking optimization- Learn, optimize picking routes for different processes on floor.
    • Learn queue, issues, patterns and take corrective/follow on actions.

     

    Please do share your feedback, ideas pertaining to your modules and your thoughts. Thanks for your time!

    Aman Orchard

entry.title: [Session Reply & Slides Available] Hot Topic: Joule Activation for SAP Cloud ERP (Public Edition)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Expertise Service Team and SAP AI RIG team recently co-present a deep-dive session focused on enabling ‌Joule‌ - SAP’s generative AI copilot - for SAP Cloud ERP.

The agenda covered as below and feel free to access [Slides] [Recording]. 

  • Business AI capabilities and use cases
  • Joule’s technical architecture on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)
  • Step-by-step activation process for S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Q&A and live troubleshooting

1. Key Objectives‌

  • Demonstrate Joule’s value in streamlining business processes (e.g., sales order management, issue resolution in status check).
  • Guide participants through end-to-end setup using BTP booster, destinations, and identity management.
  • Equip partners to deploy Joule for customers with minimal friction.

2. Business AI & Joule Introduction‌

Joule Definition‌
  • SAP’s generative AI copilot embedded in cloud solutions to automate tasks, provide contextual insights, and reduce manual effort.
Primary Use Case‌:
  • Navigational support (e.g., finding apps without memorizing transaction codes)
  • Transactional support (e.g., creating insights cards, resolving incomplete sales orders)
  • Informational support (e.g., find SAP Help document for relevant business process)
Demo Highlight
  • Create Insights Cards with Joule
  • Check Sales Order Status with Joule‌:Joule identifies incomplete orders, highlights missing fields (e.g., payment terms), and guides users to resolve issues

3. Technical Architecture & Activation Flow‌

3.1 Core Components‌:

  • Joule Web Client‌ is embedded across SAP cloud solutions (e.g., SuccessFactors, S/4HANA)
  • BTP Subaccount‌
    • Hosts Joule instance
    • SAP Build Work Zone
    • connectivity services
  • Cloud Identity Services‌
    • Manages authentication (IAS)
    • Identity / role synchronization (IPS)
  • S/4HANA Cloud APIs‌: Data source for Joule’s responses.

3.2 Activation Steps‌:

Prerequisites‌:
  • BTP global account with Joule entitlements
  • S/4HANA system registered to BTP
BTP Subaccount Setup‌:
  • Create subaccount in preferred region/hyperscaler
  • Assign entitlements:
    • SAP Build Work Zone (foundation or standard edition)
    • Joule service
  • Establish trust to Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Add S/4HANA domain to trusted destinations
Joule Booster Execution‌:
  • Guided setup for BTP formations.
  • Integrate S/4HANA, Build Work Zone, and Cloud Identity Services
Post-Booster Configurations‌:
  • Verify communication arrangements in S/4HANA (e.g., Digital Assistant Service - 0882).
  • Verify BTP Destinations
  • Verify SAP Build Work Zone Content for S/4HANA
  • Configure Identity Provisioning (IPS) to sync users/roles from S/4HANA to Build Work Zone
Validation‌:
  • Ensure Joule icon appears in S/4HANA Launchpad.
  • Test capabilities (e.g., querying open sales orders).

4. Critical Notes & Pitfalls‌

  • Trust Configuration‌: Ensure all solutions in a Joule formation use the ‌same Cloud Identity Services tenant‌.
  • Destination Errors‌: Verify hostnames, client IDs, and secrets in navigation service manually if not auto-generated.
  • Identity Provisioning‌: Ensure IPS jobs run successfully to propagate roles to SAP Build Work Zone.

5. Next Steps & Resources‌

  2. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4452/4738/
